resources.string:
There are many reasons for following a gluten free diet, including:
 
•	Coeliac disease
•	Non-coeliac gluten sensitivity 
•	Wheat or gluten allergy
•	Irritable Bowel Syndrome
•	Autoimmune diseases, including rheumatoid arthritis and multiple sclerosis
•	Personal choice

Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

Coeliac disease is an auto-immune disease causing a reaction to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye. Sufferers react abnormally to ingesting gluten, causing the intestine to become inflamed and damaged.

Symptoms may include: 
•	Diarrhoea
•	Constipation
•	Bloating
•	Chronic fatigue
•	Anaemia
•	Failure to thrive in children
•	Weight loss
•	Mouth ulcers
•	Depression
•	Infertility
 
Presentation of the disease varies from patient to patient, and some may present no symptoms at all.

Diagnosis of coeliac disease requires a blood test, followed by an intestinal biopsy during a gastroscopy. It is possible for a blood test to give a false negative.

 The only treatment for coeliac disease is a lifelong gluten free diet.

A “gluten free” label on food indicates that the product contains less than 20 parts per million of gluten. This is a level deemed safe for coeliacs to consume.

The Crossed Grain is an internationally recognised symbol that identifies a food product as being gluten free.

When checking ingredients lists, it is important to check for many hidden and obvious sources of gluten:
•	Wheat, and any derivatives
•	Rye 
•	Barley
•	Oats
•	Spelt
•	Malt, and any derivatives (excluding Malt Vinegar)
 
If a product “may contain” any of the above ingredients, coeliacs are advised not to consume them.
 
The most up-to-date information about what a food contains will always be found on its label. While the food list aims to keep an accurate listing of gluten free products, ingredients may change before the list can be updated. Therefore, coeliacs are always advised to check the label of any food products before they consume it.

Oats do not contain gluten but may be contaminated by gluten containing grains during processing. Coeliacs should only consume oats that are labelled gluten free.\n\nA minority of coeliacs are still unable to tolerate gluten free oats and so must exclude them from their diet.

The information provided in this application is as up-to-date as possible, but the most up-to-date information will always be found on a product’s ingredients label. Always check the label of a food product before consuming it.
